item.title: Trump Tries to Sway GOP Senators to Embrace Tax Bill
item.description: President Donald Trump pressed Republican holdouts on Monday, urging them to move swiftly on his multi-trillion dollar tax bill, which faces opposition from both moderates and ultra-conservatives in the Senate. Tyler Kendall reports on Bloomberg Television.

item.title: Ping An Insurance Seeks $1.5 Billion in Convertible Bonds
item.description: Ping An Insurance (Group) Co. of China Ltd. plans to raise HK$11.8 billion ($1.5 billion) through convertible bonds, according to deal terms seen by Bloomberg News, marking the insurance giant’s second such offering in under a year.
item.dc:creator: Dave Sebastian

media:content.media:description: The Ping An International Financial Center in Beijing. Bloomberg

item.title: China Holiday Spending Shrinks as Consumer Sentiment Stays Weak
item.description: Expenditures by Chinese consumers failed to pick up during the Dragon Boat Festival holiday even though more people hit the road, reflecting subdued consumer confidence in an economy reeling from US tariffs, despite a trade truce.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Fran Wang

media:content.media:description: Visitors gather and take photos on Huanghe Road, in Shanghai.

item.title: US Futures Fall as OECD Cuts Global Growth Outlook: Markets Wrap
item.description: US stock futures fell as a warning by the OECD about global economic growth reinforced concern over the impact of the Trump administration’s trade war.
item.dc:creator: Andre Janse Van Vuuren, Julien Ponthus

media:content.media:description: The Institute for Supply Management’s manufacturing index edged down 0.2 point last month to 48.5. The ISM’s import measure dropped 7.2 points, one of the largest monthly slides on record, to 39.9. Mike McKee reports on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Corrects to show third month of contraction)

item.title: Secretary Rollins on Global Agriculture Trade, US Farmers
item.description: US Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins discusses foreign purchases of US agriculture products, concerns about food additives and treatments, steps taken to recalibrate global trade programs, and protections for US farmers. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: OPEC Raises Oil Output as Group Begins Bumper Set of Increases
item.description: OPEC raised oil production last month as the group began a series of accelerated increases spurred by Saudi Arabia, according to a Bloomberg survey.
item.dc:creator: Grant Smith, Julian Lee, Bill Lehane

media:content.media:description: Pipes feed crude oil to a tanker at the Ras Tanura oil refinery in Saudi Arabia. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

item.title: Nvidia’s $1 Trillion Rally Has Traders Primed to Ramp Back Up
item.description: Nvidia Corp. shares have staged a $1 trillion rebound in two months — and investors are betting the rally has further to go as fears about the firm give way to optimism.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Vlastelica, Carmen Reinicke

item.title: Akio Toyoda Plans $33 Billion Buyout Bid to Tighten Grip on Toyota’s Founding Firm
item.description: Toyota Industries Corp., the original company that brought forth the world’s biggest carmaker, will be privatized for ¥4.7 trillion ($33 billion) by a group led by Akio Toyoda — a move that could hand the founding family a stronger grip on Japan’s biggest business empire for significantly less than its current market value.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Takahashi

item.title: South Africa Sees $49 Billion of Debt Savings With New CPI Goal
item.description: A lower South African inflation target coupled with a revised borrowing strategy could save the government as much as 870 billion rand ($49 billion) in debt-service costs, according to a research document published by the nation’s central bank.
item.dc:creator: Katlego Mtshali

media:content.media:description: South Africa’s current inflation regime hasn’t been altered since its adoption 25 years ago. Photographer: Waldo Swiegers/Bloomberg

item.title: Snowflake CEO Shares M&A, Partnership Approach
item.description: Snowflake CEO Sridhar Ramaswamy discusses the company’s latest acquisition of Crunchy Data and its partnership with the LA Olympics. Ramaswamy joins Bloomberg’s Caroline Hyde ahead of the Snowflake Summit. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Gold Retreats as Dollar Recovers Ahead of US Job Market Figures
item.description: Gold dipped as the dollar recovered ahead of US labor data later this week that will help steer the Federal Reserve’s monetary policy.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ryan, Sybilla Gross

media:content.media:description: An employee arranges gold bars at the Italpreziosi SpA precious metals refinery plant in Arezzo, Italy, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. Gold fell, snapping a two-day advance, as signs of progress on US-China trade talks curbed demand for havens even as military hostilities between India and Pakistan escalated. Photographer: Alessia Pierdomenico/Bloomberg

item.title: Eurostat to End Media’s Pre-Release Access to Euro Indicators
item.description: The European Union’s statistics office said it will end early access to pre-releases to media as of September.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Schneeweiss

item.title: Trump’s ‘Revenge’ Tax Could See Dollar Dive 5%, Allianz CIO Says
item.description: A foreign tax provision in US President Donald Trump’s massive fiscal package could trigger a 5% plunge in the dollar and send equities reeling if it takes effect, according to Allianz SE’s chief investment officer Ludovic Subran.
item.dc:creator: Alice Gledhill, Anna Edwards

item.title: Lee: Very Little Staffing Impact From UK Non-Dom Reforms
item.description: Nearly one year into Britain's Labour government, sentiment in the City of London is shifting, with new tax rules seeing an exodus of wealthy non-doms. Meanwhile, asset managers are pushing back on mooted pension reforms, whereas a much-hoped-for boost to deals has yet to materialize. Tiina Lee, Citi's UK chief executive joins Bloomberg's Francine Lacqua to discuss. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: OECD Slashes Global Forecasts Amid Trade Uncertainty
item.description: OECD Chief Economist Alvaro Santos Pereira discusses the Paris-based organization’s decision to slash its global economic growth forecast to 2.9% this year, down from 3.3% in 2024. “There’s been a huge increase in trade and economic policy uncertainty,” he tells Bloomberg Television. “This is having an impact on consumer confidence, on investors’ confidence, and also on activity indicators.”

item.title: Insight with Haslinda Amin 6/3/2025
item.description: Insight with Haslinda Amin, a daily news program featuring in-depth, high-profile interviews and analysis to give viewers the complete picture on the stories that matter. The show features prominent leaders spanning the worlds of business, finance, politics and culture. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Euro-Zone Inflation Slows Below 2%, Backing More ECB Cuts
item.description: Euro-area inflation eased more than expected, dipping below the European Central Bank’s 2% target and supporting the case for interest rates to be lowered further.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

item.title: Emerging-Market Stocks Gain as China Data Refuel Stimulus Hopes
item.description: Emerging-market stocks advanced for the first time in three days as a slump in China’s factory activity increased bets on more economic stimulus.
item.dc:creator: Selcuk Gokoluk

item.title: Red Bull Heir Transfers $1.1 Billion Stake to Geneva Trust Firm
item.description: When an Austrian marketer and a Thai businessman decided to launch Red Bull to the world, they settled on a simple ownership structure: each would own 49% of the venture.
item.dc:creator: Anders Melin, Pui Gwen Yeung

item.title: Wall Street Games Out How to Profit From Trump Tariff Flip-Flops
item.description: As trade worries bubble up once again in US markets, some on Wall Street are gaming out how to take advantage of the wild tariff-related selloffs and rallies that have defined the first five months of 2025.
item.dc:creator: Bernard Goyder

item.title: Full Implementation of 899 Not Being Priced In: Allianz
item.description: Ludovic Subran, chief investment officer at Allianz, discusses the retaliatory tax item buried in President Donald Trump’s massive fiscal package. The item, in legislation that passed the House as Section 899, would increase rates for individuals and companies from countries whose tax policies the US deems “discriminatory.” Wall Street analysts are warning the provision would create another disincentive for foreign investors. Subran speaks on Bloomberg Television.

item.title: StanChart CEO Winters Says Private Credit to Keep Its Edge Over Banks
item.description: Private credit firms enjoy a significant capital advantage over traditional banks, according to Bill Winters, chief executive officer of Standard Chartered. "I don't think that's going to change anytime soon. The result of which is banks are disadvantaged lenders," Winters said in an interview with Bloomberg's Francine Lacqua. He also discussed the UK regulatory climate and the impact of US tariffs on the financial industry. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oil Holds Gains as Canada Wildfires Offset OPEC+ Output Hike
item.description: Oil rose for a second day, as supply disruptions from Canada’s wildfires countered OPEC’s latest bumper supply increase.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley, Sarah Chen

item.title: Malaysia’s Largest Pension Fund 1Q Income Drops on Volatility
item.description: Malaysia’s state retirement fund reported a 13% year-on-year drop in investment income for the first three months of the year due to volatility in global markets.
item.dc:creator: Ram Anand

item.title: ECB Pushes Banks to Fix Shortcomings in Private Market Exposures
item.description: The European Central Bank’s top bank supervisor said the watchdog is pushing lenders to address shortcomings in how they manage risks from their dealings with direct lenders and buyout firms.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Comfort

item.title: JSW Neo Energy Seeks $675 Million Loan for O2 Power Deal
item.description: India’s JSW Neo Energy Ltd. is seeking a loan of about $675 million to back its purchase of renewable energy platform O2 Power from Sweden’s EQT AB and Singapore’s Temasek Holdings, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Chien Mi Wong, Saikat Das

item.title: Carlos Slim Is Quietly Becoming Pemex’s Partner of Last Resort
item.description: The transformation of Mexico’s richest person into its most important oil baron came about slowly, almost subtly. Carlos Slim built up a stake in Talos Energy Inc. before flipping it for the company’s Mexican unit. There was a 2023 deal for $530 million to buy a pair of oilfield assets from a fellow billionaire. Then a $1.2 billion plan to develop a gas deposit in the Gulf of Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Amy Stillman, Scott Squires, Andrea Navarro

item.title: Iron Ore Falls as China PMI Slips to Lowest Level Since 2022
item.description: Iron ore and base metals dropped on concerns about China’s economic outlook, as a gauge of the country’s manufacturing activity fell to its lowest level in more than two years.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Gemmell

item.title: CIMB to Name Malaysia’s Former Top Regulator Syed Zaid as Chairman
item.description: CIMB Group Holdings Bhd., the top underwriter of Malaysian stocks and bonds, is set to name the former head of Securities Commission Malaysia, Syed Zaid Albar, as chairman, people familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Netty Idayu Ismail, Elffie Chew
